I’m considering how scoring works, and it looks like I might only get about 20 chips base, times two, plus additional chips from the cards used in two pair—though that won't be significant. The remaining deck has some good options, so I can also consider going for a straight or flush, but aiming for a full house or trips seems more feasible since I already have three pairs. Given that, I should probably discard the non-pair cards.
**Deciding on card discards**

I’m realizing that 9S and 8H are singletons, so I could discard them to draw two new cards. I’m considering whether to discard one of the pairs to focus, but keeping all pairs might give me more chances to match. To maximize drawing a third card, it makes sense to ditch the two singletons (9S and 8H). I could consider discarding 3H, but that would mean losing one of my pairs. Since I already have two other pairs, I think it's better to discard just the two singletons to keep my pairs intact.
**Weighing discard options**

I can discard up to five cards, but if I discard just two, I get to draw two new ones, which might be enough for my strategy. I’m wondering if I should toss 8H, 9S, and maybe one of the 3s. If I get rid of 3H, I’d only keep 3C, losing the potential for a pair. While I could still aim for trips if I draw two more 3s, there are only two left, making it tricky. However, I have pairs of AA and 77, so maybe it’s fine to discard. But I should think carefully since losing 3H reduces my chances for a full house later.
**Calculating potential hands**

I’m calculating potential chip values from different hands. Discarding two cards gives me a chance to draw two new ones, which might help me hit a better hand. I’m weighing the benefits of keeping pairs for a full house versus going for straights or flushes. With the Zany Joker, I need to focus on hands that trigger additional multipliers, meaning having three of a kind is crucial. I need to strategize my discards to maximize my chances of drawing beneficial cards, starting by discarding 8H and 9S to try for more impactful combinations that could win me enough chips.
**Planning next moves**

Next, I need to calculate what happens after discarding two cards. I’ll end up with six cards, keeping my pairs of AA, 77, and 33. # Available Commands
The possible commands in Balatro are all composed of a single word specifying the action, followed by any necessary positional arguments, which are lists of integers.
Note: all position arguments are 1-indexed.

The following commands are available in your current game state.
use_consumable <consumeable_position> <target_card_position1> <target_card_position2> ... <target_card_positionN> - Use a consumeable from the consumeables section. The first position argument is the position within your consumables inventory of the consumable you'd like to use. Subsequent position arguments specify the cards in hand that the consumeable will be used on, if that consumeable requires targets.
sell_consumable <consumeable_position> - Sell a consumeable from the consumeables section.
rearrange_jokers <joker1> <joker2> ... <jokerN> - Rearrange the list of currently owned jokers. Every index in the list of current jokers must be present, i.e. if there are 5 jokers, the indices 1-5 must be present.
sell_joker <joker_position> - Sell a joker from the jokers section.
play <card1> <card2> ... <card5> - Play the selected cards and draw new ones from the deck. You may play up to 5 cards at a time. If you play a hand, you must also respond with the intended hand type you think you are playing, and an estimate of the number of chips you think you will earn from the hand. Use the results of previous hands played to inform your estimate.
discard <card1> <card2> ... <card5> - Discard the selected cards and draw new ones from the deck. You may discard up to 5 cards at a time.
rearrange_hand <card1> <card2> ... <cardN> - Rearrange the hand of cards. Every index in the list of current cards must be present, i.e. if there are 5 cards, the indices 1-5 must be present.
